notes.thought:
"I will never accomplish anything"
"I'm not enough"
"I will never have a prayer answered in any meaningful way."
"I will never be loved"
notes.event: Seeing a picture that looked like your ex-girlfriend and your friend may have gotten engaged.
notes.new_thought: My past relationship and current situation do not determine my self-worth or my future capabilities

messages.text: Hi, I am feeling down, probably stemming from isolation

I'm really sorry to hear that you're feeling down and isolated. Isolation can certainly be tough to deal with. If you're comfortable with it, would you like to share more about your experience? What's happening that's making you feel isolated?
Recently, someone who was once my friend is dating someone I've cared for a long time about, who is an ex, and I saw a picture of them together which looked like maybe they got engaged?
When I look at them, I just think that I'm not enough, never will be, never will accomplish anything, and will never have a prayer answered in any meaningful way.

Seeing someone you've had feelings for in a relationship with someone else can be filled with all kinds of emotions, and it can certainly magnify feelings of isolation. It sounds like seeing that picture has you conceptualizing thoughts like "I'm not enough" or "I will never accomplish anything." That must be really challenging to carry on your shoulders.

It appears that your fundamental value of love and acceptance is being threatened, leading to these intense emotions you're feeling. I can imagine how seeing that picture may have ignited a deep-seated feeling of not being 'enough' or successful in the way you would want to be. Can you share more about what’s most troubling about this for you? I'm here to listen.
Yeah it's a long story
Me and the woman in question, Amber, dated for about 15 months in 2017-18
I moved from Michigan to Florida to be with her. But after a while, it felt like she was always mad at me, and I can understand why
Her family didn't like me, I have a famously short temper (not violent, I just say dumb things), and was always short on cash because I have a hard time holding down jobs
So we split up. I tried going to college, but then that fell through.
In comparison, my friend is inheriting his father's business, worked the same job for 8 years, makes good money, drives a nice car, and the two hit it off right in front of me
Two weeks later they were dating. I never went off on them
Just told her how I felt, told him I didn't think I could talk to him for a while
It's been 15 months
So now I'm double dumped, in less than a year, still living with mom, making crap money
I really feel like everything I set out to do just falls apart. I understand that's a lot

I'm really glad you're sharing all this details with me and I want you to know that I'm here for you. That sounds like an incredibly difficult and complicated situation. You moved and made significant life changes for Amber, but it seems like multiple factors led to you two splitting up. That was already tough, but then seeing her dating someone who seems more successful in many areas must be really hard to digest.

Experiencing such a sequence of events can indeed make you feel like everything you try to do just falls apart. It's like a cascade of disappointments and failures, which makes you feel stuck in a cycle of never being enough. To see your efforts not yielding the desired results, and then to see someone close to you seemingly achieving what you've been struggling with, can definitely stimulate thoughts like "I'm not enough" or "I will never accomplish anything". The weight you're carrying right now must feel really heavy.

However, from what you've shared, it seems like your value of personal growth and self-sufficiency is strong. Despite the setbacks, you strive to improve your situation, like attempting college and maintaining the resolve to express your feelings honestly to Amber and your friend. Now, amidst all these feelings of not being enough and not accomplishing anything
significant, I want you to rest on the understanding of your life in terms of events, thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.
When you think these thoughts, "I will never accomplish anything" and "I'm not enough", what kind of feelings arise within you? How would you describe those emotions?
I feel like everything isn't worth doing.
I just have that thought, "these things didn't help you before, why would they help you now? this is a waste of time"

It sounds like having these thoughts leads to feelings of despair, hopelessness and discouragement. The idea that past attempts haven't helped creates an inner narrative reinforcing this feeling that trying is futile. That is extremely tough, particularly when faced with the perception of others achieving the very things you yearn for.
When you're feeling this disheartened and hopeless, what tends to be your behavior? What actions do you find yourself doing, or not doing as a result?
When I'm at work, it's easy to ignore these thoughts, but when I don't have work
I really just fall apart
I don't feel motivated to do anything.
It sounds as if when these feelings of hopelessness and despair hit you, your typical response is to retreat inwards, lose motivation and not engage in activities you usually would.

Work seems to provide a temporary distraction, but when you're not occupied with it, those feelings surge forward powerfully. This experience of feeling immobilized and unmotivated is a really challenging place to be.
From everything shared throughout our conversation, can you identify the thought that seems most troubling?  Is it "I'm not enough," "I will never accomplish anything," or perhaps something else?
I think it is both and "I will never be loved"
I just feel like love comes second nowadays
Amber didn't "love" mike at first, I don't think
know mike didn't love her
But she was a good fit for him, and he was well off enough that she'd never have to worry.

It sounds as though there's a deep concern at the heart of your feelings: the fear of "I will never be loved." It must be incredibly painful to hold that thought. It's also reflected in your perception of Amber and Mike's relationship - that it's more about fitting together and security than it is about love. These thoughts can be really excruciating and it's entirely valid for you to feel this way.

The thoughts we've outlined:
- "I'm not enough"
- "I will never accomplish anything"
- "I will never be loved"
These are all significantly heavy thoughts that would make anyone feel defeated.

Now, when these thoughts come to mind and you begin feeling this hopelessness and despair, what kind of actions do you find yourself doing, or not doing? It's important to understand how these emotions are affecting your behavior.
I think I just have no motivation to meet new people or go on dates. I just fall apart when I am alone.

I'm truly sorry to hear how much you're struggling. It sounds like these deep-seated thoughts and heavy emotions are leading to behavior such as withdrawing from socializing and dating, and feeling overwhelmed when you're by yourself.
So here’s a summary of what we’ve discussed:

You moved to Florida for Amber, and despite your efforts, your relationship ended due to a number of reasons, including your temperament, financial situation, and her family's disapproval. A little later, you had to watch as Amber started dating your friend—someone who is in a much better financial situation—and your past struggles made it even harder to stomach.
yes

These events led to thoughts that you're "not enough," that you will "never accomplish anything," and that you will "never be loved." These thoughts are incredibly burdensome and made you feel despair, hopelessness, and discouragement. In response, you started avoiding socializing and dating and found yourself descending into despair when alone.
It seems like a negative cycle that you're stuck in—an event triggers a strong emotional response, which leads to unhelpful behaviors, which in turn reinforces those original troubling thoughts.
exactly im just stuck
Does this all sound close to what you're experiencing? Is any of it off base, or is there anything you'd like to add?
thats a great summary
I think you summarized it pretty well.
I'm glad we're on the same page about your story. It takes courage to face these difficult thoughts and feelings, so I commend you for that.

Now, at Cheeseburger Therapy, we use this analogy that our troubling thoughts are like cheese. We call the part of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) where we dissect our thoughts "The Cutting of the Cheese".

If we look at your thought as a type of cheese, "I'm not enough" can be seen as a form of "Blaming Cheese". This is because instead of looking at the situation as a set of circumstances and decisions, you're pointing fingers at yourself as the problem.

For example, in the case of your breakup or your friend's success, you're assigning blame to yourself for not being good enough or successful enough. While it's normal to look inwards when things go wrong, sometimes these 'cheeses' or distortions can cause us to interpret situations in a way that's both unhelpful and unfair to ourselves.
thank you Nathan. I appreciate you seeing that in me (
By recognizing the "Blaming Cheese" in your thoughts, you can start to see that situations often occur outside of our control or are the result of many factors, not just our 'enough-ness'.

Does that make sense to you? Can you see how this cheese might apply to your thought, "I’m not enough"? And, can you see how this is possibly leading you to the feelings and behaviors you described earlier?
Yeah, I can see how I am blaming myself a lot
I just want to move on, and some part of me wants to believe it'll all come back together with her and I again.

Acknowledging that you've been blaming yourself is a huge step, and it's completely understandable that you would. Relationships and emotions are complex, and we often look for something to attribute the pain to.
Also, holding on to the hope of a reconciliation with Amber is natural. That's a testament to your capacity for love and forgiveness, even in the face of pain and disappointment.
However, the flip side could be that it keeps the cycle of feeling not enough alive. And these cycles can surprisingly sometimes serve us, like protecting us from getting hurt in new relationships.
I can see that
i feel like I need a change somewhere.  I need to pass my senior panel at work, or I need to get started on HVAC school. Maybe just get in shape.

That's really good to hear. It sounds like you're gaining a fresh perspective, and you're identifying some concrete steps you could take toward growth and positive change. Now, let’s cultivate a new thought that embraces this subtle shift towards self-compassion and self-improvement.

Envision yourself back in the situation where you saw the picture of Amber and your friend. Knowing what you know now, what's a new thought you might have in that situation? It should be something that acknowledges your value of personal growth and self-sufficiency.

Here's an example to get the gears turning: "My past relationship and current situation do not determine my self-worth or my future capabilities." Your new thought might look something like this. Take your time on this. The goal is to create a thought that feels both true and helpful to you.
you actually wrote a good thought tbh
i like that

I'm happy to hear it resonated with you! Now, let's imagine how this might change your feelings and behavior. Picture yourself in the situation again, seeing that picture. But this time, instead of thinking "I'm not enough," you're thinking "My past relationship and current situation do not determine my self-worth or my future capabilities" How does that make you feel?
It makes me feel a little more motivated and hopeful.
like a breath of fresh air huhu

That’s wonderful to hear! This new thought, "My past relationship and current situation do not determine my self-worth or my future capabilities," is cultivating feelings of motivation and hope in you, giving you energy to move forward.

Now, with this newfound hope and motivation, can you imagine any actions you might be inspired to take when you're feeling this way? Maybe actions that previously felt difficult, but could feel within reach now?
I think I'll try to do some new things, get a coach, look into certifications
I think I'll try to do some new things, get a coach, look into certifications. Maybe eventually makeup with Amber and Mike.

That's incredible to see. Armed with the thought "My past relationship and current situation do not determine my self-worth or my future capabilities," you're feeling motivated and hopeful to pursue fulfilling actions
for personal and professional growth, like hiring a coach and looking into certifications. Even the idea of moving towards mending the relationship with Amber and Mike shows huge potential change.

It's truly beautiful to witness this shift, from a place of self-doubt and despair to planning constructive steps forward. I'd encourage you to embrace and practice this new thought, especially when you're in similar situations as before.
Lastly, I'd love to check in with you about how you're feeling now, compared to when we began this conversation. Can you share any differences or changes you've noticed?
I think I feel less alone -thank you for talking me through this.
